div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: ENGLISH COMPANIES IN EGYPT.
div.p: Persons interested in the, management of the many companies registered in England, but whose sphere of operations is in Egypt, should keep an eye on the companies bill. It is said that no less than two hundred and fifty companies, doing business in Egypt and the Sudan, are English so far as registration and legal liabilities are concerned. Whether this estimate be exaggerated we cannot say, but there are a great number of English companies in Egypt, and they must come within the purview of the Companies Bill as soon as it becomes law. The rapid progress that has been made with this Bill has been one of the features’ of the;Session.. At one time it was thought that ‘the bill was not seriously intended to pass this Session, and it was for that reason, it will be recalled, that Lord Avebury introduced his own measure dealing with one or two questions’ affecting the practical working of ‘the company world. These points, however, were contained in the Government measure introduced immediately afterwards. Its rapid progress in the House of Lords has given the bill a workmanlike appearance, and with the third reading of the measure concluded on Thursday last, it is hoped that its progress through the House of Commons will not be delayed. It is not at all a measure likely to arouse opposition, and the new provisions, if practical, are notparticularly controversial, so that itis expected thatthe measure will become law this Session without any difficulty. In one direction the new Companies Bill must be welcomed; it takes avery smallstep, in the direction of strengthening the hands of auditors, the only real safeguard the investor has. Highly important in this respect is Clause 24 Section 4. This makes it necessary that if any other is to. be elected auditor than the auditor retiring hisnomination must be made to the company not less than fourteen days before the annual meeting, and the company must send such notice to every shareholder at least seven’ days before the meeting. The only objection from the point of view of honest company management is that it probably does not leave the shareholders with quite sufficient notice, but it is a step in the mght direction. It will do something to support auditors who haye had to make themselves unpleasant for a directorate that wishes to eject them. It will allow auditors some little time to circularise on their own behalf, and we trust that if occasion arises they will not be slow to avail themselves of it. As things are at present, the auditor is too muchaundet the heel of the directorate. This pointshould be carefully borne in mind by the members of’ the boards of directors of Anglo-Egyptian ‘companies for if it be neglected considerable trouble ‘will ensue.

Apropos of Companies, a recent fine inflicted on an English company in Japan affords an interésting object lesson for Egypt. Besides Egypt and other parts of the Ottoman Empire, Capitulations exist in China, Japan and élsewhere. Japan, however, is stronger than Egypt and.is determined to prevent the scandal of limited liability companiés, whose field of operations is in Japan, being immtne from interference in this respect, His Majesty's Embassy at Tokio reports a ‘decision of some importance to British companies doing business in Japan, which was recenjly given in the case of a company whose head office is at Hong Kong. This company was prosecuted for not.complying »with certain regulations of Japanese Company Law, and was fined under Article 258 of the Commercial Code, which runs as follows. “A foreign company which sets up a principal office in Japan, or which makes it its principal object to do business in Japan, most, even though it is formed in a foreign country, comply with the same provisions as though it were formed in Japan.”

It is a pity that the Egyptian Government cannot enact some such regulation, fore however wise may be the provisions of the English Companies acts, it is obvious to most people that we require here a good deal less latitude than is permitted at home.

Presence of mind is the quality which above all others, the military\, man should cultivate. “Captain, we are entirely out of ammunition.” said an orderly sergeant to his commander on a field day. “What entirely out of ammunition ?” exclaimed the captain. “Yes, entirely out,” was the reply. “Then cease firing,” said the captain.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has appoited thirty agents to fight the cotton worm in the Dakahlieh Province.
The total payments made by the Public Works Ministry for Esneh Barrage up to the end of last mouth amounted to L.E.91,089.
The Bulgarian Agency at Alexandria will be under the direction of Mr. Michailoysky, the 1st ‘Secretary, during the absence of Mr. Vernazza, chargé d'affaires.
The meeting of the general committee for the institution of a memorial to Lord Cromer will take place this aftérnoon at 5 o'clock at the Alexandria Municipality.
Owing to the very many serious accidents due to persons jumping off the trams in Cairo while in motion the Company has decided to issue, notices calling attention to the danger of such proceedings.

The construction of the telegraph line, which ‘is to unite Alexandria with Mersa Matrouh, is being pushed on through the Mariont district. A credit of L.E. 7,000 has been opened for the purpose, of which L.E. 2,029 has been expended.

In yesterday's issue of our local contempomry, “La Réforme”, there was a very justifiable complaint against the manners of one of the staff of the telephone employés, whose rudeness has led to numerous complaints, It is to be hoped’ that the ‘Telephone Company will see that some punishment is inflicted on this person, as rudeness in such a case is quite inexcusable.

div.head: NILE VALLEY (NEW) COMPANY
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the Nile Valley (New) Company was held at Winchester House on Wednesday week to confirm a resolution to increase the capital of the company to £262,500 by the creation of 250,000 additional shares of 1s, each, Mr. R.J Price, M.P., who presided, said he did not think there was any doubt in the minds of the shareholders as to the prudence of the adoption of the resolutions, in order to prevent the possibility of a disastrous breakdown, At present the mere breaking down of a motor intght plunge the company in serious pecuniary difficulties.
Mr. Samuel de Lissa seconded, and the resolutions were confirmed.

div.head: COLLAPSE OF A HOUSE
div.p: TWENTY PERSONS BURIED
THE OFFICIAL "REPORT"

A terrible catastrophe occurred yesterday evening in Alexandria, About half past eight a house in the Rue Batouta, off Sisters’ Street, collapsed anil buried in its ruins over twenty Europeans who inhabited it. The death toll to be attributed to this disaster is not as yet known, but the body of one dead man has been recovered and five persons, whose death is almost certain, remain ander the ruins at the time of writing these lines ; in addition to this 17 persons are lying in hospital more or less seriously injured. The house, which had a frontage of more than twenty metres and was three stories high, was built only a year ago, and we have been informed that its collapse is due to it being built upon old’ and unsound foundations ; for this we cannot vouch, but at the same time it is not an improbable explanation of the disaster.

The importance of the lesson afforded by this disaster cannot be exaggerated and we cannot but blame the official authorities for permitting the erection of unstable buildings. We do not with to accuse the authorities of indifference in'such matters, but we desire to point out that they invite such an accusation by offering to the Press such an inexact account of the disaster that we refuse to publish it. We have ourselVes seen that two stories of the house have collapsed, whereas the official report says “A ‘roof of a house in the Labban quarter collapsed.” ‘Ten persons are reported officially to have been rescued, while we learned at least two hours before taking the report that 17 were lying in hospital, and the report concludes “it is hoped that there are no more persons under the ruins,” when it was known by the public that others still remained either to be rescued or recovered dead.

We have also been asked to protest against the attitude of the police at thes time of the collapse. We are informed that several Europeans volunteered to assist inthe rescue of the unfortunate victims, but were driven back by blows from the shawishes’ batons and with imprecations which we cannot print. We do not vouch for the accuracy of this, but at the same time we have no reason to doubt the good faith of our informants, one of whom is a compositor of the “Egyptian Gazette”.

We desire to bestow the greatest praise upon the “Societa dei Soccorsi d’Urgenza,” who arrived on the scene of the disaster in the least possible time and did their utmost to give first aid to the injured, whom they afterwards took to the hospital.
We must also comment upon the earnest efforts of Hopkinson Bey, Cobbe Bey, Mr. Lloyd Davies, and others, to effect a speedy rescue of the victims as soon as they arrived on the spot.

Messrs. Almagia brought all their labourers from the harbour to clear ‘away the ruins, which are being excavated with great care as it is known that victims still are buried and perhaps alive. The Italian Consular authorities are superintending the work.

A peculiar coincidence is to be noted in reference to the tragedy, which in its way is grimly humorous. Yesterday afternoon the Public Works Committee of the Alexandria Municipality examined the projected regulations in regard to buildings. It was decided to submit the scheme at the next ameeting of the Municipal Commission.

div.head: THE RED SEA SURVEY
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Suez, Tuesday.
H.M.S. “Fantome,” which was lately surveying the coast near Gemsah in the Gulf of Suez, has returned to this post, ‘and is sailing this afternoon for Australia.

div.head: YACHTING IN ALEXANDRIA
div.p: The magnificent steam-yacht “Titania” recently purchased by Hussein Pasha” Fakhry in England has arrived in Alexandria harbour, She is a fine cruising vessel and very well known in English waters, being a familiar figure at all Cowes regattas. Yachting in Alexandria is going ahead by leaps and bounds and is especially encouraged by the advent of yachts of the “Cuhona” and “Titania” class, while we understand that before the end of the season we shall in all probability see further arrivals of both steam and sailing yachts. Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan is especially to be thanked for his encouragement of this most generally popular of maritime sports. As president of the Khedivial Yacht Club he has greatly advanced the interest taken in yachting by residents in Egypt, and his sportsman-like nature is an incitement to continual progress in the class of yachts competing.

As a secure anchorage and a harbour adapted to cruising Alexandria has few, if any, rivals in the Mediterranean. The yachtsman is always sure of a steady breeze and comparatively smooth water. The position of the clubhouse of the Khedivial Yacht Club is unique, standing on a promintory bounded on one side by the harbour and on the other by the Mediterranean.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM
div.p: POLICY OF SECRET SOCIETIES

In our issue of Saturday last we reproduced a remarkable article from ‘Al Watan,” the Coptic vernacularrgan of Cairo, ou the recent development of a dangerous symptom of Egyptian Nationalism, the growth of seoret societies in this country. ‘The Nationalist Press attempted to deny the charge. “Al Watan” in its issue of Tuesday last makes the following reply :—

As usual our last article on secret societies was quoted and contradicted by the Nationalist organs the day after its appearance, The contradiction took the familiar form of denying statements without proof, and of maligning the editor who writes our articles in “English and Arabic on these subjects. In fact, personal abuse and religious agitation are the only weapons wielded by these Nationalist writers in defense of their political principles. But we can afford to treat these tactics with the contempt they deserve.

Facts cannot, however, be denied with such ease, and the additional proofs published by us yesterday will leave no doubt that a form of secret societies for unpraiseworthy ends does exist in the land, A correspondent wrote te us from Alexandria that he saw a meeting of the nature we described, and that valgar agitation against Europeans and Christians in general was the main object of that meeting. Others have written to our contemporary “Misr” from Upper Egypt confirming the same news. Yet our friends of Nationalist views deny the whole story as usual and call us: traitors bécanse we dare to reveal a sinister fact. We notice that these ‘papers are almost reviling H. H. the Khedive now in answer, to certain statements made by H. H. to Mr, Dicey and published by that gentleman, who is also called an enemy now, in the “Daily Telegraph” Mr. Dicey was until the other day one of the heroes worshipped by his'present detractors because he had published a criti¢ism of Lord Cromer’s policy. But we bad been under the impression that Nationalist plotters will draw the line at the name of the Khedive. How poor in prophecy ‘and calculation we must be!

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive will leave Alexandria on the 25th June on the “Mabroussa” and will stop at Rhodes to see his daughter. His Highness will proceed thence to Constantinople were he will spend a week and will then go to Kissingen to take the waters. Fakhry Pasha, Ahmed Zeky Pasha and Izzet Bey will accompany the Khediye to Constantinople.
Sir Eldon Gorst had an interview with the Khedive in Ras-el-Tin Palace this morning. Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, was received in a private audience by the Khedive this morning.

div.head: THE MISSING DETACHMENT.
div.p: OFFICER'S BODY FOUND

It is reported that the body of the officer, Ali el Hassan, who was. in command of the detachment of 25 men, which left Bir-Natron more than a month ago, has been discovered by one of the search parties. No particulars, however, are as yet forthcoming as to exactly where the distressing discovery was made or asto the possible cause of death; but it is generally supposed that he must have died from exposure, and starvation. The fate of the remainder of the party is still uncertain but it is feared that the severe sandstorms, which have been raging iu the district south of Abou Tabari must haye caused sad havoc in their ranks. ‘The search is still being diligently continued.

Bir Natron, which they left last month, is on the Forty Days Road (Darb el Arbain) from Darfour and Kordofan to‘Assiout. It is also called Bir Sultan and is in the heart of desert 283 miles west of Dongola. Here natron is found in a seam from half an inch to two inches thick.
The “Sudan Times” of Thursday last says:—

“No new information has been received about the party of Camel Corps, which lost its way on the desert south of Abu Tabari. The party, we are told, were trying to make their way to Debba. They had guides with them; but the guides, it seems, lost their bearings, and the party had to divide. A part arrived at Dongola, and notified the authorities about their comrades, when search parties were organized and sent out to look for them,

div.head: ATTACKED BY BEDOUINS
div.p: Further details of the remarkable attack on a stranded British steamer by Bedouins have come to hand. On April 4 last the steamer Kilburn left Barry for Japan, and on April 27 she ran ashore in the Red Sea, three days’ steaming from Aden. One officer and several men put off in a small boat for that port, in order to try and obtain assistance, leaving the captain and the remainder of the crew on board the wreck. The small boat safely reached Aden, whence a salvage steamer was immediately despatched, but some days later the latter vessel returned, having failed to locate the position of the Kilburn.

Meanwhile, a large number of Bedouins had appeared on the shore near the stranded steamer, and their numbers growing stronger daily they at last determined to attack the depleted crew. Notwithstanding a gallant resistance, the British sailors were driven overboard by sheer weight of numbers, and had to take to their boats. They were afterwards picked up in the Sea by a salvage boat from Perim, where they were landed. The captain/of the Kilbburn has appealed to. the naval authorities at Aden for protection while the salvage work is being undertaken.

div.head: EGYPT'S CENSUS
div.p: EXTRAORDINARY MISTAKES

Evidence is accumulating to show that the recent census has been nating nor less than a farce. The most elementary qualification of the officials employed in taking the census should have been that they were sufficiently instructed in the elementary principles of arithmetic to do ordinary simple addition. But they appear, so far at least as Alexandria is concerned, to have been quite unable to add, For example one hundred of the census books used in the enumeration of the population of Alexandria have been examined and in every one of these books there was a mistake in the addition, The total errors in these sixty books resulted in giving two thousand persons less than. were actually enumerated. For the numbering of Alexandria thirty thousand of such books were employed at the last census, so if there were the same amount of errors in all of them, as has “been found to be the case in the hundred books inspected, there is an a¢tual shortage of no less than 60,000 in the reported population of Alexandria, solely due to mistakes in simple addition.

The shortage in the reported’ population from sheer slackness in not visiting houses, must amount to a far higher figure. On every hand evidence is forthcoming from well-known European residents of Alexandria ‘and Cairo, whose houses were never visited by the census enumerators, We could instance many flagrant cases of such omissions, but one will suffice to show the wilful neglect of the employés of the Census Department. The Alexandria headquarters of the Eastern Telegraph Company is such a large building and is situated in such a central part of the city that it would be thought impossible to miss it. The telegraph office of the company is known to everybody, yet we are informed by the superinterident that he was never asked by any employée of the Census Department to fill inany paper or make any statement. Yet there are about thirty Englishmen sleeping there every night. If. such oversights were committed amongst the European inhabitants, who, after all, are easily reached, the numbers of such oversights must have been plenteously multiplied in the case of the natives, who are by contrast difficult to locate. The figures belie themselves, too. Between 1882 and 1897 the population increased by 43 was not absolutely accurate, but an increase of barely 15 per cent., as has been registered between 1897 and 1907, spread over a period when the European influx:to' Egypt has been, enormous, and during which the prosperity of the country has been growing, must be, on the face of it, far below the mark, The Egyptians aré’ essentially a prolific nation, which is one more argument for a larger increase in the population.

The figures only’ show an increase of 70,000 and 61,000 in the population of Cairo and Alexandria respectively, the former numbering 640,000 and the latter 377,000 inhabitants. Such increases are absurdly small ones, and taking a comparative statement of the total census this year and in 1897, in all its published sections, one has to come to the conclusion that there is something wrong.

If a census is to be of any use it must be as accurate as possible, and no doubt the fault lies with the Government, who, to economise, ‘appointed as census-inspectors men already in the Government service, who had to do the work gratis, Of course, in a good many instances, outside men were taken and paid for their services, but- the greater part were unpaid. This would account for oversights and inaccurate figures.

It is a pity that the Government did not accept the offer of the Alexandria Municipality, which undertook to carry out the census for this city for,a total sum of L-E. 1,500. This amount was considered too dear, and the result has been that many people are wondering how it is that the municipal tax-collectors are able to ferret them out, while they were left severely alone by the officials of the census.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: THE FUTURE OF HELOUAN

p.hi: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

div.p: Sir, – Helouan, the only climacteric centre in Egypt is renowned for its hot sulphur spring, its pure desert air and its high level. The town with beautiful wide roads is built on the Mokattar Hill and commands a nice scenery of the desert, the Nile with the palm trees and the pyramids of Saakkarah and Gnizeh.
For people suffering from rheumatism, chest or skin diseases Helouan is the only resort, as it is for weak people and children.

Helouan was rapidly progressing when the late Khedive Tewfick Pacha was living there, but his death affected it considerably as the late railway Company has since considerably slacked in their duties.

Several residents called the attention of the | Company and appealed to the Government, and Lord Cromer, with the result that the conces. in sion, was transferred from the Helouan Railway Company to the Delta Light.

The Delta soon started improving the railway, and in fact the line was doubled up to Tourah, four new big first class and four second class carriages arrived, the stations have been nicely painted and supplied with nice flower pots.

The waiting rooms have been properly furnished and the number of trains has been increased, as now there is an hour train service. The residents are feeling now more comfortable and the railway receipts have increased 150% which is to be appreciated, and announces a very good future for Helouan. We will see before two years the population increasing from 7,000 to 20,000 if the railway continues the improvements.

In the beginning of last winter several residents had an interview with the Manager of the Helonan Railway, Capt. Adams, and asked the doubling of the line from Tourah to Helouan, the conversion of the steampower into electricity, renewal of the stock, the extension of the line to Berombol East of Atfih district and other improvements. The Manager I promised to look into the matter and do all in his power for the comfort of the population. At the end of the winter season Capt. Adams saw that the doubling of the line would be convenient for the Company's interest and proposed to the Board the sanction of the improvements mentioned.

In fact the Board accepted the proposal and wrote to the Ministry of Public Works to that effect. But as the total expenditure of LE. 100,000 cannot be redeemed within the short time of the concession that still remains, more especially as L.E. 60,000 have already been spent a short time ago, the Company asks from the Government, the extension of the concession for a sufficient length of time to allow them to redeem the sum they will spend on improvements.

When the Helouan residents saw that the railway has done all they could to meet their wishes, they have addressed a petition in triplicate to Sir Eldon Gorst, Sir W. Garstin and Sir. Vincent Corbett requesting them to accept the Railway Company's scheme.

Sir Eldon Gorst replied to the undersigned that the Ministry of Public Works is now considering several proposals concerning the improvement of communications between Cairo and Helouan, and that our request will be forwarded also for consideration.
Hassan Bey Mazloum the Secretary of Sir Vincent Corbett replied in the latter name that all his efforts will be displayed for the benefit of the Helouan town.
Now I will detail what the Helonan residents ask from the Government and the Railway Company.
From the Railway Company they ask : –
1) The doubling of the line from Tourah to Helouan.
2) The renewal of its rolling stock.
3) The conversion of steam power into electricity.
4) The departure of a train from each end every 1/2 hour (if possible every 15 m.)
5) The extension of the line up to Berembal Atfih District.
From the Government.
6) The extension of the Delta Railway concession to redeem the new capital required for improvements asked.
7) A road of 20 m. width from Cairo to Helouan, for which all land at St. George, Sahel, Neadi, Tourah, Massara and Helouan will benefit.

This road will increase the value of all properties and a tax may be imposed on same. Several other Companies will also considerably benefit through this road, as the Delta Land Company, The Automobile Co., Helonan Improvement Co., The Automobile Club. This road will be the best promenade for Automobiles and carriages as it will run near the river and the scenery will be splendid

8. To open a credit of 20 or 80,000 pounds for improvements in Helouan such as planting trees in the streees, making trottoirs, metalling the roads and building public gardens etc., all this to be completed within 2 or 3 years at the most.
9. The reduction of the cost of the water which is now higher than in Cairo.
10. The improvement of the electric light which is actually poor.
11. The filtering of the water, and we heard the Government is looking into these two latter points.
12. Granting a concession to "El Hayat” or any other Company for making a tramway line, either pulled by horses or electricity from Helouan to the river.
This is what the Helouan residents ask and which will make of Helouan the most beautiful | healthy centre of Egypt, and we hope that those

concerned will display their efforts in giving the Helouan its proper share in the improvements. | It may be said that the Government cannot dispose of all the money required but there is such an extension of land belonging to the Government at Helooan and its surroundings and at Tonrah and Meadi and certainly these improvements will increase the value of the land and by this way the Government will also largely share in the profits made through these improvements.

The Helouan town requests that the local newspapers will assist their scheme as much as possible, they also ask the legislative members to side with them, as it is a shame that Egypt should possess only one climacteric centre with baths and it should be neglected whilst in the occident there are so many places in the same Kingdom and all of them so nicely attended to. For most of Helouan inhabitants
and proprietors
Naquib CHAKRA
Lawyer and proprietor
of Magallet El Estiklal.

div.head: CAESAR'S CAMP.

p.hi: To the EDITOR OF THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

div.p: Having already been victimised by the freaks of the tram company, allow me to express my regret that the "Unsatisfied Well. known Solicitor" did not complete the comedy he has striven so hard to describe in his letter to the “Gazette" of to-day, under the above title..

Sarah Bernhardt was pulled away from before the train, but it does not appear that the same was done to the irate solicitor, so I fear he has no excuse for not having immolated himself and by so-doing he would perhaps have induced the charitable managers of the train company to relieve the growing population represented by the unsatisfied solic itor. It is really a pity! It would at least have saved him the trouble of trudging into town.
Yours truly,
DULCAMARA.
Alexandria, May 29th 1907.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha, according to some local newspapers, is engaged to a daugh, ter of the Sultan. The rumour is absurd zus the Princesses of reigning Moslem families when they marry are not allowed to leave the Capital.

Lord Cromer who is getting used to the change of climate and surroundings, is staying in the neighbourhood of Portland Place, but, owing to his health, is keeping very much aloof from social entertainments. His lordship will, according to present arrangements, re. main in town till the middle of July, but he is as yet undecided whether he will spend the autumn in England or on the Continent. Lady Cromer's name appears constantly in the papers as attending social functions or first nights at the theatre, so Lord Cromer's friends in Egypt may feel assured that his lordship is going on satisfactorily.

A certain quantity of Lord Cromer's private effects have been offered for sale by auction; that is to say those of insufficient value to. justify their transport to England. The sale | commenced last Thursday and lasted for two | days, and was attended by many hunters after souvenirs, not unmingled with bargain seekers, as the articles offered for sale were much to be desired. The sale took place at the house of Mr. Wilfred Carey, opposite the | Agency.

The Sirdar and his suite arrived at Khartoum yesterday week by special train. During his short stay at Erkowit and Port Sudan, the Sirdar made a visit to Suakin, and the visit was made an occasion of festivity by the people of that city. The town was gaily decorated, and large crowds met his Excellency at the railway station. At the mudirieh offices his Excellency held a levee at which a large number of officers, officials, merchants and notables were present. In responding to an address of welcome, his Excellency said that Suakin had maintained and would continue to maintain its importance, on account of its proximity to Port Sudan.
Captain R. D. B. Blakeney, R.E., Deputy General Manager of the Egyptian Railway Administration, left Alexandria yesterday by the S.S. "Ismailia" for Athens and Constanti: nople and thence to England.

The marriage of Mr. S. R. P. Carver and | Miss Gertrude Mary Malden will take place as originally arranged in Salisbury Cathedral on Saturday, the 1st proxo., but quite quietly owing to the recent death of Mr. S. H. Carver.
We regret to hear that the Rev. Peter Rudolph is seriously ill owing to inflammation of the liver, from which he has been suffering for the last three weeks.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Menoptbah sailed from Liverpool yesterday afternoon and is due here about the 12th proxo, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: TELEGRAMS
div.p: GROWERS AND SPINNERS.
Vienna, May 29.
The Cotton Congress discussed methods for strengthening direct relations between the actual growers in America and the spinners in Europe to the exclusion of market manipulators.

The European delegates, while welcoming closer union, made it clear that they could not afford to slacken their efforts to extend cottongrowing to other countries. There was too much risk run in keeping the supply subject to the climatic conditions of one country. The Congress also discussed the badness of American baling, and resolved to favour legislation against placing’ extraneous matter in bales at ginneries. (Reuter)
GENERALS’ SUCCESSION,
London, May 29.

it is officially stated that Generals Sir N. Lyttelton, Sir W. G. Nicholson, Lord Methuen, Sir J. L. Oliphant, and Sir A. H. Paget will succeed Generals Lord Grenfell, Sir N. Lyttelton, Sir H. J. T. Hildyard, Sir Leslie Rundle, and Lord Methuen respectively as the vacancies occur. (Reuter)
ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
EDITORS’ VISIT TO BERLIN.
BERLIN, May 29.
The English journalists have arrived and were cordially greeted. In a toast at the dinner which was givén, M. Muhlberz welcomed the end of the mistrust between Erigland and Germany. (Havas)
CANTON, May 29.
1,300 troops have left for Swa-Tan ; another detachment will follow from Shinhing. ‘The malcontents have captured a Brigadier-General's entire family and compelled them to commit suicide by drowning.

The Svatyan revolutionary society proclaims the rising as not directed against foreigners, the intention being to burn eyery yamen and to exteriniyate the officials with the object of overthrowing the Government. Missions have been untouched, but the missionaries are taking refuge at Swa-Tau. (Renter)
LONDON, May 29.
It is stated that Mr. Chamberlain feels confident of being able to attend Parliament next session. (Reuter)
PARIS, May 29.
M. Falliéres will go to Norway in September. M. Pichon gave a banquet to King and Queen of Norway. (Havas)
PARIS, May 29.
Queen Alexandra has left for England. (II)
ST. PETERSBURG, May 29.
The Duma refused to discuss a motion ceusuring the terrorists. (Havas)
LONDON, May 29. ;
Essex heat Lancashire by four wickets. The South Africans beat M.C.C. hy three wickets. Kent beat Derbyshire by an innings and 100 runs. The match between Yorkshire and Hampshire was drawn. (Reuter)

div.head: EGYPTIAN RAILWAYS
div.p: FRED-WATER HEATERS

A German firm of engineers has recently completed a passenger engine for the Egyptian State Railways. A feed-water heater has been fitted, and as the engine has given good results as regards fuel consumption, it is suggested that these heaters would tend to allow of more economical working on passenger lines. In the United States the feed-water heater has been occasionally adopted, but it has never become popular. Probably it has been thought: that the complications and repairs necessary were too numerous.’ The first part of the heater in the above mentioned locomotive consists of a vertical cylinder, which is placed between the driving wheels on the same side as the pump. There is a nest of tubes inside the cylinder, and the feed-water circulates around these tubes; through the latter passes the exhaust steam from the pump. This pump draws water from the tender and forces it into the first part of the heater After being warmed in, the first heater the feed-water passes into another heater, which is situated just above the forward truck. And then on to a third cheater, which is located on the left-hand side of the engine, The exhaust steam from the main steam chests exhausts into this part of the apparatus. The exhaust is then led up the stack. Before actually entering the boiler, the feed-water passes through a number of tubes in the smoke-box. It is supposed that this arrangement gives a saying in coal consumption of over 20 per cent. Whether the complication is worth this saving depends, among other things, upon the price of coal.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: (FROM OUR FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT)

There is some slight tightening of the market for cash supplies, which is, however, of a quite temporary character, The statistics which we quote below give no grounds for supposing that there will be any stringency of gold for some time to come. The position generally is astrong one, and thoughts are beginning to turn rather to the possibility of a change of affairs in the Autumn, it not being considered likely that any special drain of gold will take place during the summer months. Should the strikes on the Rand have the effect of reducing production, this might have a serious aspect, but it would appear as if the mine-owners were quite content to take the chance which the strike affords of eliminating the undesirable workers, and taking on new and better hands, of which there appears to be an abundant supply. It is not thought, therefore, that any serious interruption of the work of the mines will take place. Some trouble there may be, owing to the strikers being superseded, and the Government of the Transvaal, having realised this, are taking strong measures to deal with any disturbances that may arise.

This week’s Bank return shows that a further £90,000 has been added to the reserve, which now stands at £24,680,000, as compared with £23,187,000 twelve months ago. Notwithstanding Whitsuntide requirements, the stock of coin and bullion is higher by £193,000 but this is doubtless explained by the recept of £306,000 in gold from abroad. “Other ” Securities are up £272,000, and Public Depositsshow an increase of £1,429,000. The Proportion of Reserve to liabilities now stands at 46.83 per cent. as against pecent. last year.

The larger proportion of the gold which has arrived from Africa and elsewhere has been bonght by the Bank of England, and although France has been a competitor, the amount secured for our neighbours has been small. Bar gold is now quoted at 77/10 per ounce standard.
Three months’ bank bills are being done at 3 3/8 per cent.
The tone of the silver market is very firm, and the price of bar silver has further advanced to 30 7/8 per ounce,

So far from the Whitsuntide holiday having given a fillip to investment business, as it was hoped might be the case, the tone of markets has this week been even more depressed ‘than ever. A feeling of extreme pessimism prevails in nearly all sections, and business has been reduced to the smallest possible limits, Needless to say prices have continued a downward course owing to the lack of support. Of course this unhappy state of thing is the result of indifference on the part of the public rather than of any specific adverse influence, but the constant declines in values is too serious for holders to be comforted by this fact,

Telegrams received from Egypt show a more or less demoralised state of affairs in the stock markets in Cairo and Alexandria. The artificial remedies proposed, and more or less carried out, to prevent undue depreciation are not believed in here. At the same time, it is admitted that in a local market such remedies may be of temporary use, as indeed, they appear to have been. One cause of the accentuation of the shimp which has taken place in Egypt is undoubtedly ‘the smallness of the market here for Egyptian securities. We have repeatedly pointed out how shortsighted was the policy of those responsible for flotations of Egyptian companies in not allotting a larger number of shares to European applicants, and thus broadening the basis of Egyptian share finance. A certain number of shares ot every company should be reserved for applicants in this country. Had this heen done, and the large initial profits made, been shared with the markets here, there would have been a sufficient number of investors interested to create a freer market for the shares’ when the depreciation occurred. By following a greedy policy these companies have deprived the British public of the fair share of the profits arising from the premium to which the shares went and it cannot be a matter of surprise that the London Stock Exchange has a languid interest in things Egyptian. To broaden the basis of Egyptian markets is an absolute necessity, and we commend this matter earnestly to the attention of those large brokers and financial houses who have to deal, with it. The tendency to supersede London boards, and place the entire management of Egyptian companies in the hands of local boards, while it may appear to be a commonsense arrangement, is in reality a very short-sighted policy. After all, Egypt in its time of development is dependént upon foreign capital, and everything that tends to give confidence to the foreign investor should be carefully preserved. London boards may not be able to superintend efficiently the management, whiph should be in the hands of strong local directors, but to have a number of men of honourable reputation here to answer for the honest and efficient conduct of the company generally is an important guarantee to the British investar, The truth of it is that in Egypt so muoh money has recently been made that financiers there have a feeling that they can look after their own affairs, forgetting that, after all, they cannot begin to finanoe themselves without the assistance of older countries with large accumulated capital and that in bed times the help of another market is essential,

Gilt-edged securities are extremely depressed, and yesterday Consols were marked down to 84(½) for money and 84. 9/16 for the account, although at the close’ they were firmer at 84, 11/16 and 84(¾), thus showing a loss on the day

Dallness reigns in the futernational market, Paris having been a rather heavy seller, Russians after being firm at the opening on Tuesday, have since gone back, and the Fives are now quoted 88(½) the Fours being down to 74(¾). Japanese have been irregular with alight declines in; two or three of the stocks.

The market for home railway shares has been quite demoralised since our last, and it is almost impossible to negotiate new business. Yesterday the feature was a slump in Brighton shares, which was due to a Tumour that the company intended to issue new capital, At one time the Deferred fell to 85(½) after opening at 893, but after the publication of a semi-official denial of the report above referred to the price rallied to 87. The Ordinary dropped 3 to 109. Under the influence of Brighton stocks other Southern shares were also weak.
Today a further fall has occurred ‘in Brighton Deferred, which close at 186(½). Other shares are 1/4 to ¾.

The general tendency of American shares has been downward, two adverse influences being the rise in the price of wheat, and heavy selling of Pacific issues from New York. On Wednesday Northern Pacific dropped 4 points to 124 and Unions 3(¾) to 138.

Yesterday the opening was rather firmer on overnight advices, but lack of support from Wall St. in the afternoon caused a further setback, Northern Pacific and Unions were further marked down 3 and 1(3/8) respectively, while Chesapeake and Ohio and Milwaukee shed 1(½).
There has been little doing in Americans to-day. Union Pacific ord. are unchanged, but the preference are higher at 88.

The Egyptian share share market has fluctuated very wildly during the last few days, and at one time it looked like breaking badly. The shares on offer were, however, taken at the low prices, and have gradually recovered; the closing tone being firmer all-round.

National Bank of Egypt were offered down to 21, but have now risen to 22(¾)-3. Agricultural Bank have been as low as 8,3/16, but a large line of shares were taken at this price, and at 8(¼), and buying continued steadily at rising prices, the quotation being to-night 8(½)-(5/8). The Preference ate nominally 9(¼)-(½). Daira, after being offered at 14(7/8), close at 15(¼). Egyptian Estates are better at 1 5/16—7/16, after having been down to 1(1/8)-(¼). Delta Land and Investment are also up.to 2}-4. Delta Preference Bearer had a nasty slump to 9(½), but all shares offering at this price were well taken. The closing price is 94-10. New Egyptian have changed hands at 18/6, and Corporation, of Western Egypt are quoted (½)-(¾). Union Fonciere at 5(¼), and Land Bank at 7(7/8) are easier. Comptoir Financier are flat and close nominally 3(¾)-4(¼). Egyptian Markets at 1,5/16 and Salt and Soda at 1 are quite unchanged.

The strike of miners on the Rand, with resulting fears that the trouble would spread, has adversely affected mining shares, although the real cause of the weakness of the market is the absence of assistance on the part of investors, There has been a great deal of liquidation, and the future is regarded with anything but cheerfulness.
The deep level’ shares have been especially depressed.

Egyptian mining shares are hae much dealt in. At the same time, from information we have received, we believe that some of these mines will show an excellent result ere long, Nile Valley at 1/8 and Egyptian Mines Exploration at 1/6 show no change.
